A Guide to the Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Business Interests, Series C FA312

did.unittitle: Office of the Messrs. Rockefeller records, Business Interests, Series C

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Open for research with select materials restricted as noted. Brittle or damaged items are available at the discretion of RAC. Material in the Rockefeller family collections that provides the names, correspondence, or activities of living members of the Rockefeller family, and/or documents the net wealth of any Rockefeller family members, is restricted. Researchers interested in accessing digital media (floppy disks, CDs, DVDs, etc.) or audiovisual material (audio cassettes, VHS, etc.) in this collection must use an access surrogate. The original items may not be accessed because of preservation concerns. To request an access surrogate be made, or if you are unsure if there is an access surrogate, please contact an archivist.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The files in this series are divided into 27 subseries of investments, as follows:

Platt-LePage Aircraft Company; Airlines; American Linseed Company; American Anglo Transvaal Company; Banks; Chase Safe Deposit Company; Bright Matter; China Industries, Inc.; Collins Brown Press; Colorado Fuel and Iron Company; Companies; Everett Timber and Investment Company; Fairway Farms; Filatures et Tissages Africains; International Business Machines, Inc.; Insurance; Marion Fruit Company; Marston and Company; Minnesota Iron Mines; New Furniture; Rockefeller Brothers, Inc.; Rockefeller Center, Inc.; Rockefeller Plaza; South America and Africa; Standard Oil Companies; Turck and Co. - Special Services; United States Steel Corporation.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: The Business Interest series documents the Rockefeller Family's investments and financial involvement in a variety of industries, companies, and geographic areas, including banks, oil, iron mining, timber, railroads, Rockefeller Center, and South America.

The series contains correspondence between members of the Rockefeller family and the Family Office on the one hand, officers and employees of the various companies on the other. The correspondence concerns all manner of management, policy and financial decisions regarding the various investments.

The family members who figure most prominently in the papers are John D. Rockefeller, Sr., John D. Rockefeller, Jr., John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Nelson Rockefeller, Laurance Rockefeller, and David Rockefeller.

There is no material in this series dated later than 1961, but members of the Rockefeller family continue to maintain an interest and investments in a number of the businesses included in this series. The files on those particular business areas are closed. There are two exceptions to this policy. The file on Rockefeller Center, Inc. and Rockefeller Plaza are open. Files containing intimate financial information about these two firms are closed. All items recommended for closing shall remain closed for fifty years from the last date in this series, which is 1961.

did.unittitle: Platt-LePage Aircraft Company
Platt-LePage Aircraft Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Helicopter company incorporated in 1938, with Laurance S. Rockefeller one of the first stockholders. Winthrop Rockefeller also a stockholder. Difficulties in development; purchase of stock by McDonnell Aircraft; liquidation of Platt-LePage. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, Winthrop Rockefeller, Harper Woodward.

did.unittitle: Airlines - McDonnell Aircraft Corporation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laurance S. Rockefeller invested in stock of newly organized corporation working on military aircraft, 1939; became a director, 1941. McDonnell-Laurance S. Rockefeller correspondence re bids, plans, politicking with the Defense Dept. Connection between General Electric and McDonnell Aircraft Corporation. Labor problems; relations with Eastern Airlines. Laurance S. Rockefeller 1942 resignation; rejoined board after war. Laurance S. Rockefeller objections to McDonnell Aircraft Corporation pledge to St. Louis Country Day School. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, James McDonnell, J. Lionberger Dunn, L. Williams, Harper Woodward.

did.unittitle: Airlines - McDonnell Aircraft Corporation - Stock Subscription

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Purchase; disposal at a loss during war to avoid conflict of interest possibilities; postwar purchases; transfer of some to Rockefeller Brothers Company. David Rockefeller and John D. Rockefeller 3rd stock sales.

did.unittitle: Airlines - McDonnell Aircraft Corporation - Platt-LePage Merger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Merger negotiations with helicopter company; collapse of negotiations. McDonnell's purchase of controlling interest in Platt-LePage. Correspondents include J. McDonnell, Laurance S. Rockefeller, R. B. Marston, Phillip Keebler, Winthrop Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Airlines - McDonnell Aircraft Corporation - Platt-LePage Merger

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Merger negotiations with helicopter company; collapse of negotiations. McDonnell's purchase of controlling interest in Platt-LePage. Correspondents include J. McDonnell, Laurance S. Rockefeller, R. B. Marston, Phillip Keebler, Winthrop Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Airlines - McDonnell Aircraft Corporation - Aluminum House Frames

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Plans to use McDonnell Aircraft Corporation production facilities to produce pre-fabricated houses. No results here. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, W. K. Harrison, J. B. McDonnell.

did.unittitle: Airlines - Inter-American Escadrille

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Designed to further Good Neighbor policy through aviation; 1941 aviation study of Latin America. Cooperation with Nelson A. Rockefeller's Coordinator office; 1942 liquidation. Laurance S. Rockefeller a director. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, Franklin Field.

did.unittitle: Airlines - Inter-American Escadrille - Contributions

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laurance S. Rockefeller made small contributions and guaranteed a note for the Escadrille.

did.unittitle: Airlines - Inter-American Escadrille - Good Will Flight

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laurance S. Rockefeller provided plane used on four-month tour of South America. Pilot training clubs organized; report on Latin American conditions.

did.unittitle: Airlines - Cairns Corporation

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Patent-holding company granting licenses to aircraft companies switched to manufacturing aircraft material. Laurance S. Rockefeller stock option, interest in one of their patented processes, guarantee of Chase loans. No interest shown after start of war. Correspondents include R. B. Barry, Laurance S. Rockefeller, John Hoffhine.

did.unittitle: Airlines - Cairns Corporation - Laurance S. Rockefeller Loans

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

did.unittitle: Airlines - Institute of the Aeronautical Sciences, Inc.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Laurance S. Rockefeller a director, contributor, benefactor member. Formation of Aeronautical Archives, with Laurance S. Rockefeller a member of Archives Committee; gifts by McCormick, Guggenheim, Paul Kollsman, to Archives and Institute; Laurance S. Rockefeller's letters of appreciation. Lester Gardner's resignation. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, Lester D. Gardner, Arthur W. Packard, Harold McCormick, Florence Guggenheim.

did.unittitle: Airlines - Barry and Wood

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Firm organized to locate manufacturing facilities for aircraft industry. Laurance S. Rockefeller small investment, no management control. Loan returned with interest. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, Eric Wood.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Produced aircraft parts; Laurance S. Rockefeller interest in sheet metal bending machine; loan to corporation. Machine unsuccessful, loan written off as bad debt. Correspondents include Laurance S. Rockefeller, Frohman Anderson.

did.unittitle: American Linseed Company
American Linseed Company - Annual Reports
American Linseed Company - Certificate of Incorporation, By-Laws
American Linseed Company - Financing

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller $3,800,000 loan to company in 1901; Frederick T. Gates' reasons for John D. Rockefeller's actions. John D. Rockefeller carried Linseed, financing its grain buying through an open account on which company drew; company paid prevailing interest rates. Problem re John D. Rockefeller's income tax. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. assumed responsibility after 1920. Correspondents include Frederick T. Gates, John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Bertram Cutler, Thomas M. Debevoise.

American Linseed Company - General Correspondence
American Linseed Company - $35,000 Bonds

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

did.unittitle: American Linseed Company - Stock for Officials

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller, Jr. financed purchase of company stock for top officials as a permanent investment, upset when some officials sold for quick profit. Interesting tax angle. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Bertram Cutler, R. H. Adams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller subscribed to newly formed Chase Securities Corporation; Bertram Cutler became member of Executive Committee in this and in Chase Harris Forbes Corporation which purchased and distributed securities for Chase Securities Corporation. Divorcement of Chase Securities Corporation from Bank, liquidation of Chase Securities Corporation, complaints of employees. Material re First Boston Corporation and family's subscription to it.

Banks - Chase Bank - Suit Against Mr. Wiggins

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Attempt by stockholders to regain some of the high salary, bonuses and profits paid to Wiggins; heard by referee, settled out of court. Chase received $2,500,000. Complaints by stockholders against Wiggins. Correspondents include Thomas M. Debevoise, A. Wiggins.

did.unittitle: Banks - Equitable Trust Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: At Frederick T. Gates' urging, John D. Rockefeller bought stock, 1911; placed Rockefeller representatives on Board. 1919, John D. Rockefeller largest stockholder, held one-sixth of total. Stock transferred to John D. Rockefeller, Jr., and General Education Board. Correspondents include Frederick T. Gates, H. E. Cooper, John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note

Parmalee Prentice, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Frederick T. Gates, J. F. Welborn.

scopecontent.p: Bowers' investigation of Colorado Fuel and Iron affairs; prices; sending of statements to John D. Rockefeller; financial difficulties of Colorado Fuel and Iron. Bowers' election as Vice President. Make-up of Executive Department; Mr. Osgood's plans to establish Victor-American Fuel Company. Explosion at Starkville Mine; allegations re employment of boys at Pueblo; explosion at Primero. Election of directors; purchase of bonds; estimated earnings; appraisal of iron and coal lands. Correspondents include LaMont Bowers, Frederick T. Gates, John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., J. F. Welborn, George J. Gould.

did.unittitle: Colorado Fuel and Iron Company - Bowers and Frederick T. Gates Correspondence - Memos and Letters

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Article on Colorado Fuel and Iron in The Survey; allegations that protection lacking and mine condition dangerous, Bowers' refutation of charges. Distribution of Colorado Fuel and Iron funds among various banks. Payment of dividends.

did.unittitle: Colorado Fuel and Iron Company - Criminal Prosecutions in Colorado - J. R. Lawson

scopecontent.p: Campaign of abuse of everybody connected with case; Starr J. Murphy advice that John D. Rockefeller made no comment while case pending. Protest from International Association of Machinists re Lawson conviction. John D. Rockefeller, Jr. comments on trial.

Osgood, Woodrow Wilson.

did.unittitle: Colorado Fuel and Iron Company - United States Commission on Industrial Relations

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Welborn's descriptions of the strike; Bowers' description of pre-strike Colorado Fuel and Iron political activity. Correspondence re early development of strike. Bowers' views re union demands, Wilson's administration, and the strike. Telegrams between Secretary of Labor, Colorado Fuel and Iron executives, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. during strike. Ivy Lee-John D. Rockefeller, Jr. letters re corrective publicity. Correspondence of direction of US Commission on Industrial Relations, McCarthy, with John D. Rockefeller, Jr. and personnel of various Rockefeller Boards. John D. Rockefeller, Jr.-MacKenzie King-Bowers correspondence re plans for company union. Ending of strike. Correspondents include Rep. Foster, Starr J. Murphy, L. Bowers, J. F. Welborn, Sec. Wilson, Ivy Lee, Dr. C. McCarthy, MacKenzie King, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Minnesota Iron Mines
Minnesota Iron Mines - Franklin Iron Mines

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Frank Rockefeller and James Corrigan's investment in Messabi Range. Franklin Mines purchased first by Corrigan; then F. Rockefeller investment. John D. Rockefeller financed to $124,000, plus additional short-term working capital; John D. Rockefeller held most of stock, 1893-1899, as collateral for loans. Several attempts by Frank Rockefeller to sell Franklin Iron Mines to John D. Rockefeller and Frederick T. Gates as part of Lake Superior Consolidated Iron Mine Company. John D. Rockefeller represented throughout by Frederick T. Gates; Frederick T. Gates also supervised ore railroad and selling of ore in 1898. 1898, John D. Rockefeller, Jr. agent for John D. Rockefeller. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Frederick T. Gates, Frank Rockefeller, James corrigan, M. A. Hanna, C. W. Rogers, H. W. Oliver.

Minnesota Iron Mines - Tilden Mining Company - Lease to Oliver Mining Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Oliver, Frederick T. Gates and John D. Rockefeller jockey for position vis a vis exploitation of John D. Rockefeller's iron lands; establishment of tie with A. Carnegie. Rockefeller companies: Lake Superior Consolidated Iron Mines, Duluth, Missabi and Northern Railroad, and Bessemer Steamship Company. John D. Rockefeller owned Tilden, a lessee from Keweenaw Associates; then sublet to Oliver, 1899-1914. Routine after 1898; exhaustion of natural resources. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Frederick T. Gates, H. W. Oliver, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Starr J. Murphy.

did.unittitle: Minnesota Iron Mines - Tilden Mining Company

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Routine administrative correspondence by company officers. Majority of stock owned by United States Steel and Rockefeller Foundation. Company practically inoperative - leased land from fee holders and directly sublet it to Oliver Iron Company. Sales of land and timber. 1927-1928, Oliver Company cancels its lease; search for new lessee; reduction of stock. Problems of mineral exhaustion. Negotiations for land. Foundation sale of stock, 1942. Correspondents include Starr J. Murphy, E. V. Cary, Charles Scheide, L. G. Myers, A. L. Boulware, Thomas M. Debevoise, Leferts Dashiel, Charles O. Heydt, C. P. Fish.

did.unittitle: Minnesota Iron Mines - Merritt Controversy

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: John D. Rockefeller investments in Minnesota Iron Company. Loan to L. Merritt through C. W. Wetmore for Duluth, Missabi and Northern Railroad. Lake Superior Consolidated Mines Company. L. Merritt debts; John D. Rockefeller loans; Penokee and Geobic failure. 1893 suits in Duluth's "populist" jury, decisions against John D. Rockefeller; appeal, reversal. 1911 Stanley investigation; Frederick T. Gates' defense of John D. Rockefeller's 1893 actions. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Frederick T. Gates, C. W. Wetmore, L. Merritt, G. W. Murray, H. R. Rogers, A. A. Harris.

scopecontent.p: Management of Frank Rockefeller's debt to John D. Rockefeller; climax in 1898 when Frank Rockefeller, on John D. Rockefeller's advice and through John D. Rockefeller's machinery, sells most of his Standard Oil Trust to liquidate indebtedness to John D. Rockefeller. Frank Rockefeller's hostility toward John D. Rockefeller - removal of children from family cemetery plot; vitriolic letter sent to William Rockefeller, which William Rockefeller showed to John D. Rockefeller. Correspondents include Frank Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller.

did.unittitle: Minnesota Iron Mines - Frank Rockefeller - Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Frank Rockefeller's sale of Standard Oil Trust stock certificates through John D. Rockefeller's office at $430; William Rockefeller predicted price would go to $500. Transaction later became serious bone of contention between Frank and John D. Rockefeller, as predicted by Mrs. Tuttle in 1898. Typed copies of original correspondence included. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, Frank Rockefeller, M. Tuttle, G. D. Rogers.

did.unittitle: Minnesota Iron Mines - Frank Rockefeller - Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Frank Rockefeller's sale of Standard Oil Trust stock certificates through John D. Rockefeller's office at $430; William Rockefeller predicted price would go to $500. did.unittitle: Minnesota Iron Mines - Frank Rockefeller - Personal

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Although alienated, John D. Rockefeller continued to loan Frank Rockefeller anonymously through William Rockefeller. Management of Frank Rockefeller's increasing debt to brothers. 1914, John D. Rockefeller's letter to Frank Rockefeller's wife. John D. Rockefeller drew out his share of special guaranteed account for Frank Rockefeller at Jesup & Lamont, 1917. Frank Rockefeller's death; John D. Rockefeller and William Rockefeller release claims to Frank Rockefeller's widow, Helen. Sale of Ohio home. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, William Rockefeller, Frank Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr.

did.unittitle: Minnesota Iron Mines - James Corrigan

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Relations between John D. Rockefeller and Corrigan; Corrigan's borrowing from John D. Rockefeller, beginning in 1886 with loans for "wheat firm" in West; also lake steamers. James corrigan and his brother John apparently had earlier connection with Standard Oil, borrowed on Standard Oil certificates. 1894 - Corrigan's iron brokerage firm in trouble, asks John D. Rockefeller for $100,000; leads to reevaluation of debts. John D. Rockefeller asks for payment. Frederick T. Gates reports Franklin Iron Mine not worth loans John D. Rockefeller made to it. New provisions for Franklin Iron Mine. Frank Rockefeller and corrigan dispute Frederick T. Gates; Corrigan sells Standard Oil certificates at $167.50. Correspondents include James Corrigan, Frank Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Frederick T. Gates, J. DeBurke Rogers.

did.unittitle: Minnesota Iron Mines - James Corrigan - Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: After clearing his Franklin Iron Mine and personal debt to John D. Rockefeller, Corrigan receives stock of Franklin Iron Mine which John D. Rockefeller had held as collateral. By 1897 Corrigan, under S. Burke's influence, felt $167.50 was too low for Standard Oil certificates; suit hinted at - arbitration resulted. Correspondents include James Corrigan, John D. Rockefeller, Frank Rockefeller, G. D. Rogers, S. Burke.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Questions and answers between John D. Rockefeller, G. D. Rogers and G. D. Murray, 1897-1898. Copies of correspondence re Corrigan suit. Correspondence between John D. Rockefeller, J. Corrigan and G. D. Rogers, October-November, 1894. Frederick T. Gates suggestion of Standard Oil Trust deal, October 1894. Stenographic notes of John D. Rockefeller and G. D. Rogers interviews with Corrigan, 1894-1895. Pencilled memoranda by John D. Rockefeller, 1896-1899. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, G. D. Rogers, J. Corrigan, G. D. Murray.

did.unittitle: Minnesota Iron Mines - James Corrigan - Correspondence

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Legal documents; some correspondence. Court of Common Pleas, Ohio, September 1900, John D. Rockefeller vs. James Corrigan. Corrigan attempt to reverse arbitrators' decision. Documents re loans to Corrigan and his sale of Standard Oil certificates to John D. Rockefeller. Corrigan, after losing series of appeals, pays off debts to John D. Rockefeller, 1901-1902. 1905, Starr J. Murphy, John D. Rockefeller and Virgil Kline reaction to Ida Tarbell attack on John D. Rockefeller re Corrigan affair. John D. Rockefeller desire to get facts before public; prepares his "final note" for future. Correspondents include John D. Rockefeller, James Corrigan, Virgil Kline, Starr J. Murphy, Ida Tarbell.

Rockefeller, Jr., Starr J. Murphy, J. D. Archbold.

did.unittitle: Standard Oil Companies - Standard Oil Company - Printed Material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Industrial Relations Plan material; "Industrial Representation Experience of Standard Oil," "Stock Acquisition Plan," "Annuities and Benefits," "From the Directors of the Standard Oil to its Employees and Stockholders," "The Directors of Standard Oil to its Shareholders." M. D. Post's "Why the $29,000,000 Verdict Was Reversed;" H. J. Howland's "Standard Oil," Chapter VI of Tarbell's "History of Standard Oil." "The Standard Oil Company" article in "The Protectionist;" Elbert Hubbard's "The Standard Oil Company," "Interview with President Taft re Standard Oil," "The Turbulent Romance of Oil" by W. C. Jenkins. "Nation" review of Tarbell's History; Fenimore Goode's "The Story of the Standard;" J. R. Day's "Reply to Rev. Thomas C. Cleveland" in Zion's Herald. Newspaper report on United States vs. Standard Oil of Tennessee decision, comment from National Corporation Reporter. "The Ethics of Standard Oil" by G. F. Wright; G. H. Montague's "Legend of the Standard Oil Company." Tarbell's "Is the Standard Oil Crumbling?"

did.unittitle: Standard Oil Companies - Standard Oil Company - Miscellaneous Material

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents note
scopecontent.p: Archbold reports to John D. Rockefeller on 1907 trial. Starr J. Murphy advice re public relations during trial; recommendation that John D. Rockefeller resign from Standard Oil; John D. Rockefeller suggested it to Archbold, who disagreed. Offers of aid o John D. Rockefeller including skeletons in Judge Landis' closet; suits brought by individuals against Standard Oil. Typed notes on Starr J. Murphy-John D. Rockefeller discussion of origins of Standard Oil. 1905 difficulties in Kansas. Requests for interviews. Standard Oil officials' views re impending suits; building up proof that John D. Rockefeller resigned from all Standard Oil companies except Standard Oil of New Jersey. Re Dr. Bacon's history of Standard Oil. Correspondents include J. D. Archbold, Starr J. Murphy, F. B. Squire, George Rogers, John D. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller, Jr., Virgil Kline.

Rockefeller, E. B. Lymen.

scopecontent.p: Organized by Nelson A. Rockefeller, Fenton Turck and Webster Todd as a service corporation in marketing and distributing merchandise. 1933, Nelson A. Rockefeller bought out partners, changed name to Special Work. Company worked closely with Rockefeller Center, Inc. renting office. Name changed again to Corporate Research, Inc. Dissolved in 1942. Correspondents include Nelson A. Rockefeller, John D. Rockefeller 3rd, Thomas M. Debevoise.
